tit.j: 大徳寺
tit.e: Daitoku-ji Temple
Daitoku-ji Temple
Daitoku-ji Temple

sen.j: 大徳寺（だいとくじ）は、京都府京都市北区 (京都市)紫野大徳寺町にある禅宗寺院で、臨済宗大徳寺派大本山である。
sen.e: Daitoku-ji Temple is the head temple of the Rinzai sect's Daitokuji school of Japanese Zen Buddhism and is located in Daitokuji-cho Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Daitoku-ji Temple is the head temple of the Rinzai sect's Daitokuji school of Japanese Zen Buddhism and is located in Daitokuji-cho Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Daitoku-ji Temple is the head temple of the Rinzai sect's Daitokuji school of Japanese Zen Buddhism and is located in Daitokuji-cho Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号を龍宝山と称する。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Ryuhozan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Ryuhozan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Ryuhozan.

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来、開基（創立者）は大燈国師宗峰妙超（しゅうほうみょうちょう）で、正中 (元号)2年（1325年）に正式に創立されている。
sen.e: The temple was formally founded in 1325 with the principal image Shaka Nyorai and Daito-kokushi Shuho Myocho serving as kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding.
sen.cmt: ・principal image: 英辞郎 on the WEB・Shaka Nyorai: http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm
sen.e: The temple was formally founded in 1325 with the principal image Shaka Nyorai and Daito-kokushi Shuho Myocho serving as kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding.
The temple was formally founded in 1325 with the principal image Shaka Nyorai and Daito-kokushi Shuho Myocho serving as kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding).

sen.j: 京都でも有数の規模を有する禅宗寺院で、境内には仏殿、法堂（はっとう）をはじめとする中心伽藍のほか、20ヶ寺を超える塔頭（たっちゅう、本山寺院の境内周辺にある関連寺院）が立ち並び、近世の雰囲気を残している。
sen.e: The Zen temple contains within its precinct many structures that are of prominance within Kyoto such as its butsuden (Buddha hall), hatto (lecture hall), central monastery and over 20 Tatchu (sub-temples).

The Zen temple contains within its precinct many structures that are of prominence within Kyoto such as a central monastery, including Butsu-den (Buddha hall), Hatto (lecture hall), and also over 20 Tatchu (sub-temples), and remains the atmosphere of the early-modern times.
sen.cmt: prominance→prominence仏殿、法堂（はっとう）をはじめとする中心伽藍、部分を原文に合わせ訂正。原文の、近世の雰囲気→an atmosphere of the early-modern times 部分を補足。
sen.e: The Zen temple contains within its precinct many structures that are of prominence within Kyoto such as a central monastery, including Butsu-den (Buddha hall), Hatto (lecture hall), and also over 20 Tatchu (sub-temples), and remains the atmosphere of the early-modern times.

sen.j: 大徳寺は歴代多くの名僧を輩出し、茶の湯文化とも縁が深く、日本の文化に多大な影響を与え続けてきた寺院である。
sen.e: Daitoku-ji Temple has played a great part in Japanese culture; having produced many eminent monks and becoming closely linked to the Japanese tea ceremony.
Daitoku-ji Temple has played a great part in Japanese culture; having produced many eminent monks and becoming closely linked to the Japanese tea ceremony.
Daitoku-ji Temple has played a great part in Japanese culture; having produced many eminent monks and becoming closely linked to the Japanese tea ceremony.

sen.j: 本坊および塔頭寺院には、建造物、庭園、障壁画、茶道具、中国伝来の書画など、多くの文化財を伝えている。
sen.e: The main temple and sub-temples represent a wealth of cultural property such as architecture, gardens, partition paintings, tea utensils, and Chinese influenced works of calligraphy.
The main temple and sub-temples represent a wealth of cultural property such as architecture, gardens, partition paintings, tea utensils, and Chinese influenced works of calligraphy.

tit.j: 起源と歴史
tit.e: Origin and History
Origin and History
Origin and History

sen.j: 大徳寺の開祖である禅僧・宗峰妙超は、弘安5年（1282年）、播磨国（兵庫県）に、同国守護・赤松氏の家臣・浦上（うらのえ）氏の子として生まれた。
sen.e: Daitoku-ji Temple's founder Zen priest Shuho Myocho was born in Harima province (present day Hyogo Prefecture) in 1282 into the Uranoe clan which served as retainers to the Shugo Akamatsu clan.
sen.cmt: ・Harima province: プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: Daitoku-ji Temple's founder Zen priest Shuho Myocho was born in Harima Province (present day Hyogo Prefecture) in 1282 into the Uranoe clan which served as retainers to the Shugo Akamatsu clan.
Daitoku-ji Temple's founder Zen priest Shuho Myocho was born in Harima Province (present day Hyogo Prefecture) in 1282 into the Uranoe clan which served as retainers to the Shugo Akamatsu clan.

sen.j: 11歳の時、地元の大寺院である書写山円教寺に入り、天台宗を学ぶが、のち禅宗にめざめ、鎌倉の高峰顕日（こうほうけんにち）、京の南浦紹明（なんぽじょうみん）に参禅。
sen.e: At age 11, he entered the local large Shoshazan Engyo-ji Temple and began to study the ways of the Tendai sect, but after awakening to Zen Buddhism, he travelled to consult with Koho Kennichi of Kamakura and Nampo Jomin of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: ・Tendai sect: 英辞郎 on the WEB、およびhttp://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=59058&a=
sen.e: At age 11, he entered the local large Shoshazan Engyo-ji Temple and began to study the ways of the Tendai sect, but after awakening to Zen Buddhism, he travelled to consult with Koho Kennichi of Kamakura and Nampo Jomin of Kyoto.

At age 11, he entered the local large Shoshazan Engyo-ji Temple and began to study the ways of the Tendai sect, but after awakening to Zen Buddhism, he travelled to consult with Koho Kennichi of Kamakura and Nampo Jomin of Kyoto.

sen.j: 南浦紹明が鎌倉の建長寺に移るにしたがって宗峰も鎌倉入りし、徳治2年（1307年）に師から印可を得た。
sen.e: When Nampo Jomin was transferred to Kencho-ji Temple in Kamakura, Shuho also entered Kamakura and received formal confirmation of his awakening (dharma transmission) from his master in 1307.
When Nampo Jomin was transferred to Kencho-ji Temple in Kamakura, Shuho also entered Kamakura and received formal confirmation of his awakening (dharma transmission) from his master in 1307.
When Nampo Jomin was transferred to Kencho-ji Temple in Kamakura, Shuho also entered Kamakura and received formal confirmation of his awakening (dharma transmission) from his master in 1307.

sen.j: その後数年、京都東山で修行を続けていた宗峰妙超は、正和4年（1315年）（元応元年＝1319年とも）、同郷の赤松則村（円心）の帰依を受け、洛北紫野の地に小堂を建立した。
sen.e: After serving at Kyoto's Higashiyama for several years, Shuho Myocho earned the devotion of Norimura AKAMATSU (Enshin) in 1315 and established a small temple in the Murasakino area of Rakuhoku.
After serving at Kyoto's Higashiyama for several years, Shuho Myocho earned the devotion of Norimura AKAMATSU (Enshin) in 1315 and established a small temple in the Murasakino area of Rakuhoku.
After serving at Kyoto's Higashiyama for several years, Shuho Myocho earned the devotion of Norimura AKAMATSU (Enshin) in 1315 and established a small temple in the Murasakino area of Rakuhoku.

sen.j: これが大徳寺の起源とされる。
sen.e: This was the origin of Daitoku-ji Temple.
This was the origin of Daitoku-ji Temple.
This was the origin of Daitoku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 花園天皇は宗峰に帰依し、正中 (元号)2年（1325年）、大徳寺を祈願所とする院宣を発している。
sen.e: Emperor Hanazono became devoted to Shuho and, in 1325, decreed that Daitoku-ji Temple be converted to a supplication hall.
sen.cmt: ・Emperor Hanazono: 英辞郎 on the WEB (-天皇)
sen.e: Emperor Hanazono became devoted to Shuho and, in 1325, decreed that Daitoku-ji Temple be converted to a supplication hall.
Emperor Hanazono became devoted to Shuho and, in 1325, decreed that Daitoku-ji Temple be converted to a supplication hall.

sen.j: 寺院としての形態が整うのはこの頃からと思われる。
sen.e: It is believed that it was around this time when the site took on the form of a temple.
It is believed that it was around this time when the site took on the form of a temple.
It is believed that it was around this time when the site took on the form of a temple.

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇も当寺を保護し、建武 (日本)元年（1334年）には大徳寺を京都五山のさらに上位に位置づけるとする綸旨を発した。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Daigo also patronized Daitoku-ji Temple and commanded that it be further elevated to the top of the Kyoto-Gozan in 1334.
sen.cmt: ・Kyoto-Gozan: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Emperor Go-Daigo also patronized Daitoku-ji Temple and commanded that it be further elevated to the top of the Kyoto-Gozan in 1334.
Emperor Go-Daigo also patronized Daitoku-ji Temple and commanded that it be further elevated to the top of the Kyoto-Gozan in 1334.

sen.j: しかし、建武の新政が終わって足利氏が天下を取ると、後醍醐天皇と関係の深い大徳寺は足利氏から軽んぜられ、五山十刹から除かれてしまった。
sen.e: However, when the Kemmu Restoration ended and the Ashikaga clan gained control of the nation, temples that held a deep relationship with Emperor Go-Daigo were looked down upon by the Ashikaga clan and this led to Daitoku-ji Temple being excluded from the Gozan-Jissetsu.

However, when the Kemmu Restoration ended and the Ashikaga clan gained control of the nation, temples that held a deep relationship with Emperor Go-Daigo were looked down upon by the Ashikaga clan and this led to Daitoku-ji Temple being excluded from the Gozan-Jissetsu.

However, when the Kemmu Restoration ended and the Ashikaga clan gained control of the nation, temples that held a deep relationship with Emperor Go-Daigo were looked down upon by the Ashikaga clan and this led to Daitoku-ji Temple being excluded from the Gozan-Jissetsu.

sen.j: 至徳 (日本)3年（1386年）には、五山十刹の最下位に近い、十刹の第9位とされている。
sen.e: In 1386, the temple was reinstated near the very bottom of the Gozan-Jissetsu as number 9.
In 1386, the temple was reinstated near the very bottom of the Gozan-Jissetsu as number 9.
In 1386, the temple was reinstated near the very bottom of the Gozan-Jissetsu as number 9.

sen.j: このため大徳寺は、政府の庇護と統制下にあり世俗化しつつあった五山十刹から離脱し、座禅修行に専心する独自の道をとった。
sen.e: For this reason, Daikoku-ji Temple withdrew from the governmet patronage, control and increasing secularization of the Gozan-Jissetsu and pursued its own path.
For this reason, Daikoku-ji Temple withdrew from the government patronage, control and increasing secularization of the Gozan-Jissetsu and pursued its own path.

For this reason, Daitoku-ji Temple withdrew from the government patronage, control and increasing secularization of the Gozan-Jissetsu and pursued its own path by engaging in ascetic practices through Zen meditation.
sen.cmt: Daikoku-ji→Daitoku-ji訳抜け補足：by engaging in ascetic practices through Zen meditation

sen.j: 五山十刹の寺院を「叢林」（そうりん）と称するのに対し、同じ臨済宗寺院でも、大徳寺、妙心寺のような在野的立場にある寺院を「林下」（りんか）という。
sen.e: Temples, including those of the Rinzai sect, outside the system such as Daitoku-ji Temple and Myoshin-ji Temple are known as 'Rinka' in contrast to Gozan-Jissetsu temples which are called 'Sorin'.
Temples, including those of the Rinzai sect, outside the system such as Daitoku-ji Temple and Myoshin-ji Temple are known as 'Rinka' in contrast to Gozan-Jissetsu temples which are called 'Sorin'.
Temples, including those of the Rinzai sect, outside the system such as Daitoku-ji Temple and Myoshin-ji Temple are known as 'Rinka' in contrast to Gozan-Jissetsu temples which are called 'Sorin.'

sen.j: その後の大徳寺は、貴族、大名、商人、文化人など、幅広い層の保護や支持を受けて栄え、室町時代以降は一休宗純をはじめとする名僧を輩出した。
sen.e: Following this, Daitoku-ji Temple enjoyed the patronage and support of a wide range of people including aristocrats, Daimyo, business people and cultural figures and, from the Muromachi period, produced a string of eminent monks eminent Ikkyu Shojun.

Following this, Daitoku-ji Temple enjoyed the patronage and support of a wide range of people including aristocrats, Daimyo, business people and cultural figures and, from the Muromachi period, produced a string of eminent monks eminent Ikkyu Shojun.

Following this, Daitoku-ji Temple enjoyed the patronage and support of a wide range of people including aristocrats, Daimyo, business people and cultural figures and, from the Muromachi period, produced a string of eminent monks including Ikkyu Shojun.

sen.j: 侘び茶を創始した村田珠光などの東山文化を担う人びとが一休に参禅して以来、大徳寺は茶道の世界とも縁が深く、武野紹鴎、千利休をはじめ多くの茶人が大徳寺と関係をもっている。
sen.e: After Higashiyama culture proponents such as wabi-cha tea ceremony creator Juko MURATA began consulting with Ikkyu, Daitoku-ji Temple came to be closely linked with the world of the tea ceremony and tea ceremony masters such as Joo TAKENO and Rikyu SEN.

After Higashiyama culture proponents such as wabi-cha tea ceremony creator Juko MURATA began consulting with Ikkyu, Daitoku-ji Temple came to be closely linked with the world of the tea ceremony and tea ceremony masters such as Joo TAKENO and Rikyu SEN.

sen.j: 享徳2年（1453年）の火災と応仁の乱（1467年 - 1477年）で当初の伽藍を焼失したが、一休宗純が堺の豪商らの協力をえて復興。
sen.e: The first monastery was completely destroyed by the fire of 1453 and the Onin War (1467-1477) but Ikkyu Shojun reconstructed it with the cooperation of wealthy merchants from the city of Sakai.
sen.cmt: ・Onin War: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The first monastery was completely destroyed by the fire of 1453 and the Onin War (1467-1477) but Ikkyu Shojun reconstructed it with the cooperation of wealthy merchants from the city of Sakai.

sen.j: 近世以降も豊臣秀吉や諸大名の帰依を受けた。
sen.e: He continued to receive the devotion of Daimyo such as Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
He continued to receive the devotion of Daimyo such as Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
He continued to receive the devotion of Daimyo such as Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期に幕府の統制を受け、紫衣事件と呼ばれる元住持・沢庵宗彭が流罪となる圧迫を受けたが、幕府との関係ものちに回復した。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, the temple fell under the control of the Shogunate and the former chief priest Takuan Soho was forced into exile in what is known as The Purple Robe Incident, but relations with the Shoganate subsequently recovered.

In the early Edo period, the temple fell under the control of the Shogunate and the former chief priest Takuan Soho was forced into exile in what is known as The Purple Robe Incident, but relations with the Shoganate subsequently recovered.

sen.j: 寺運は栄え、今日に至っている。
sen.e: Temple activities continue to flourish until today.
Temple activities continue to flourish until today.

tit.j: 伽藍
tit.e: Monastery
Monastery
Monastery

sen.j: 勅使門、三門、仏殿、法堂（はっとう）がほぼ一直線に並び、これら中心伽藍の北・南・西に20ヶ寺以上の塔頭寺院が並ぶ。
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys), Sammon gate and the hatto (lecture hall) are arranged in almost a straight line and the monastery around which these are centered is surrounded by over 20 sub-temples.
sen.cmt: ・Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys): http://p-www.iwate-pu.ac.jp/~acro-ito/Japan_pics/Japan_KYE/imageidx.html・Sammon gate: http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・hatto (lecture hall): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys), Sam-mon gate, Butsu-den and Hatto (lecture hall) are arranged in almost a straight line and the monastery around which these are centered is surrounded by over 20 sub-temples.
sen.cmt: Chokushi-monとなっているので、Sam-monに修正。Butsu-denを補足。Hattoに修正。
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys), Sam-mon gate, Butsu-den and Hatto (lecture hall) are arranged in almost a straight line and the monastery around which these are centered is surrounded by over 20 sub-temples.

sen.j: 勅使門（重要文化財） - 慶長年間（1596年 - 1614年）建立の御所の門を下賜され、寛永17年（1640年）に移築されたもの。
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (Important Cultural Property) - The imperial palace gate constructed between 1596 and 1614 was bestowed to the temple where it was relocated in 1640.
sen.cmt: ・Chokushi-mon gate (the Gate for the Imperial Envoys): http://p-www.iwate-pu.ac.jp/~acro-ito/Japan_pics/Japan_KYE/imageidx.html・important cultural property: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (Important Cultural Property) - The imperial palace gate constructed between 1596 and 1614 was bestowed to the temple where it was relocated in 1640.
Chokushi-mon gate (Important Cultural Property) - The imperial palace gate constructed between 1596 and 1614 was bestowed to the temple where it was relocated in 1640.

sen.j: 三門（重要文化財） - 2階建ての門。
sen.e: Sammon gate (Important Cultural Property) - A two storey gate.
sen.cmt: ・Sammon gate: http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・important cultural property: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Sam-mon gate (Important Cultural Property) - A two storey gate.
Sam-mon gate (Important Cultural Property) - A two storey gate.

sen.j: 連歌師・宗長の寄進で享禄2年（1529年）にまず下層のみが竣工し、天正17年（1589年）、千利休が上層（2階）を完成させたという。
sen.e: The lower storey alone was completed in 1529 using funds donated by renga poet Shocho and the upper storey was completed in 1589 by Rikyu SEN.
The lower storey alone was completed in 1529 using funds donated by renga poet Shocho and the upper storey was completed in 1589 by Rikyu SEN.
The lower storey alone was completed in 1529 using funds donated by renga poet Shocho and the upper storey was completed in 1589 by Rikyu SEN.

sen.j: 利休は上層に自身の木像を安置した（つまり、門をくぐる者は利休の下を通ることになる）が、これが豊臣秀吉の怒りを買い、秀吉はこのことを楯に利休に自決を迫ったという。
sen.e: Rikyu installed a wooden statue of himself in the upper storey (so that those who pass through the gate must pass below Rikyu), but this enraged Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI who used this as a pretext for pressuring Rikyu to commit suicide.

Rikyu installed a wooden statue of himself in the upper storey (so that those who pass through the gate must pass below Rikyu), but this enraged Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI who used this as a pretext for pressuring Rikyu to commit suicide.

sen.j: 仏殿（重要文化財） - 寛文5年（1665年）、京の豪商・那波常有（なわじょうゆう）の寄進で建てられた。
sen.e: Butsuden (Buddha hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1665 using a donation from wealthy Kyoto merchant Joyu NAWA.
sen.cmt: ・Butsuden (Buddha hall): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・important cultural property: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Butsu-den (Buddha hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1665 using a donation from wealthy Kyoto merchant Joyu NAWA.
Butsu-den (Buddha hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1665 using a donation from wealthy Kyoto merchant Joyu NAWA.

sen.j: 法堂（はっとう、重要文化財） - 寛永13年（1636年）、小田原城主稲葉正勝の遺志により、子の稲葉正則が建立した。
sen.e: Hatto (lecture hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1536 by Masanori INABA in order to fulfill the dying wish of his father Odawara Castle lord Masakatsu INABA.
sen.cmt: ・hatto (lecture hall): http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm・important cultural property: 英辞郎 on the WEB・Odawara Castle: http://www.kanagawa-kankou.or.jp/english/area/odawara.html、http://yushu.or.jp/english/e_sdate/00jpn/00pref/00oct27f1.html
sen.e: Hatto (lecture hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1636 by Masanori INABA in order to fulfill the dying wish of his father Odawara Castle lord Masakatsu INABA.
Hatto (lecture hall) (Important Cultural Property) - Constructed in 1636 by Masanori INABA in order to fulfill the dying wish of his father Odawara Castle lord Masakatsu INABA.

sen.j: 方丈および玄関（国宝） - 方丈は寛永12年（1635年）、玄関はその翌年、豪商・後藤益勝の寄進で建てられたもので開祖大燈国師（宗峰妙超）300年遠忌を記念して新築されたものである。
sen.e: Hojo (Abbot's quarters) (National treasure) - Constructed in 1635 using funds donated by wealthy merchant Masukatsu GOTO in order to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the death of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho), with the entranceway being built in the following year.

Hojo (Abbot's quarters) (National treasure) - Constructed in 1635 using funds donated by wealthy merchant Masukatsu GOTO in order to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the death of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho), with the entranceway being built in the following year.

Hojo and entranceway (Abbot's quarters) (National treasure) - Constructed in 1635 using funds donated by wealthy merchant Masukatsu GOTO in order to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the death of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho), with the entranceway being built in the following year.

sen.j: 「方丈」は元来は住職の居室を指したが、日本の禅寺の方丈は接客・儀式空間の意味合いが強い。
sen.e: The word 'hojo' originally referred to the main priest's living quarters but in Japanese Zen Buddhist temples, hojo have more of a significance as spaces for receiving visitors or holding rituals.
The word 'hojo' originally referred to the main priest's living quarters but in Japanese Zen Buddhist temples, hojo have more of a significance as spaces for receiving visitors or holding rituals.
The word 'hojo' originally referred to the main priest's living quarters but in Japanese Zen Buddhist temples, hojo have more of a significance as spaces for receiving visitors or holding rituals.

sen.j: 通常の方丈建築は、前後2列、左右3列の計6室を並べる平面形式が多いが、大徳寺方丈は前後2列、左右4列の計8室をもつ特異な形式で、向かって右から2列目の2室は、開祖大燈国師（宗峰妙超）の塔所（墓所）である雲門庵となっている。
sen.e: Conventional hojo architecture often consists of a total of 6 rooms arranged in a 2x3 arrangement but that of Daitoku-ji Temple is different in that consists of a 2x4 arrangement of 8 rooms with the second room of the second row serving as the tassho (burial place) of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho).

Conventional hojo architecture often consists of a total of 6 rooms arranged in a 2x3 arrangement but that of Daitoku-ji Temple is different in that consists of a 2x4 arrangement of 8 rooms with two rooms of the second row on the right serving as the tassho (burial place) of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho), Unmon'an.
sen.cmt: the second room of the second row→two rooms of the second row on the right ※2室は部屋二つ、という意味。二番目の部屋では無い。雲門庵→Unmon'an を補足。
sen.e: Conventional hojo architecture often consists of a total of 6 rooms arranged in a 2x3 arrangement but that of Daitoku-ji Temple is different in that consists of a 2x4 arrangement of 8 rooms with two rooms of the second row on the right serving as the tassho (burial place) of founder Daito-kokushi (Shuho Myocho), Unmonan.

sen.j: 宗峰は、「自分の死後に、墓所として別の寺院を建てるには及ばぬ」と遺言していたため、このような形式になっている。
sen.e: This is because Shuho stated in his will, 'After I pass away, I am not worthy of having another temple built simply to serve as my burial place'.
This is because Shuho stated in his will, 'After I pass away, I am not worthy of having another temple built simply to serve as my burial place'.

sen.j: 禅宗では本来、広く人材を募る「十方住持制」をとっているが、大徳寺はこの制度によらず、開祖宗峰妙超の法系の僧のみを住職とすることを認めた文書である。
sen.e: Zen Buddhism originally recruited widely under the Jippo-Jujisei system of succession to the abbacy in Zen temples, but Daitoku-ji Temple was not involved in the system and this letter recognizes that only those monks who were followers of Shuho Myocho could be installed into the role of abbot.
